title: 104_hr125
content: The "Gun Crime Enforcement and Second Amendment Restoration Act of 1996" aims to protect citizens from armed violent criminals by focusing on arresting, convicting, and incarcerating offenders to prevent them from quickly returning to the streets. The Attorney General must establish an armed violent criminal apprehension program within 180 days of the Act's enactment. Each US attorney must appoint a prosecutor and create a task force to develop strategies for removing armed violent criminals from the streets, considering factors like punishment deterrence, laws, resources, and the nature of the crimes. The Attorney General requires US attorneys to report on violent crime in their districts and the prosecution of certain federal crimes. The Attorney General also submits reports to Congress on this information and waivers granted. US attorneys can request waivers from the Attorney General for certain requirements. The Attorney General may waive requirements for US attorneys based on guidelines considering the number of assistant attorneys and level of violent crime. An "armed violent criminal" is defined as someone accused of specific gun-related offenses after a previous violent crime conviction. This section will expire after five years from the enactment of the Act. The text chunk discusses the repeal of prohibitions on semiautomatic assault weapons and large capacity ammunition feeding devices, along with mandatory prison terms for possessing, brandishing, or discharging a firearm during a federal crime of violence or drug trafficking. Section 924(c) of title 18, United States Code is amended to include mandatory prison terms for possessing, brandishing, or discharging a firearm during a federal crime of violence or drug trafficking. Possession results in 5 years imprisonment, brandishing in 10 years, and discharging with intent to injure in 20 years. The amendment to Section 924(c) of title 18, United States Code mandates prison terms for possessing, brandishing, or discharging a firearm during a federal crime of violence or drug trafficking. Possession results in 5 years imprisonment, brandishing in 10 years, and discharging with intent to injure in 20 years. For certain types of firearms, additional sentences of 10 or 30 years may apply. Subsequent convictions carry harsher penalties, including a minimum of 20 years imprisonment for possessing a firearm during the crime. The amendment to Section 924(c) of title 18, United States Code mandates prison terms for possessing, brandishing, or discharging a firearm during a federal crime of violence or drug trafficking. Possession results in 5 years imprisonment, brandishing in 10 years, and discharging with intent to injure in 20 years. For certain types of firearms, additional sentences of 10 or 30 years may apply. Subsequent convictions carry harsher penalties, including a minimum of 25 years imprisonment for discharging a firearm with intent to injure, and life imprisonment for certain types of firearms. Probationary sentences are not allowed, and imprisonment terms do not run concurrently with other crimes. "No person sentenced under this subsection shall be released for any reason during a term of imprisonment imposed." The House of Representatives passed the bill on March 22, 1996. Attest: ROBIN H. CARLE, Clerk.
